EN

The provided text outlines details for two executive interviews from the FMLS:25 summit. The first segment features Dor Eligula, Co-Founder of BridgeWise, discussing the integration of AI in investment research and analytics for brokers. He highlights growth opportunities in Asian markets, the synergy between automation and human analysis, and offers advice for retail investors on using AI tools effectively. The second segment focuses on an interview with Brendan Callan, CEO of TRADU, who argues against the current proprietary trading model. Following a debate on the industry's reliance on prop trading, Callan critiques the model for being overly dependent on fees, loose on risk management, and potentially misleading for retail clients.

Key Points

  • BridgeWise Co-Founder Dor Eligula discusses AI's role in broker analytics and Asian market expansion
  • Eligula highlights the balance between automation and human judgment in financial research
  • TRADU CEO Brendan Callan criticizes the current prop trading model's risks and fee structures

Article

Executive Interview | Brendan Callan | CEO, TRADU | FMLS:25 Executive Interview | Brendan Callan | CEO, TRADU | FMLS:25 Executive Interview | Brendan Callan | CEO, TRADU | FMLS:25 Executive Interview | Brendan Callan | CEO, TRADU | FMLS:25 Executive Interview | Brendan Callan | CEO, TRADU | FMLS:25 Executive Interview | Brendan Callan | CEO, TRADU | FMLS:25 Brendan Callan joined us fresh off the Summit‚Äôs most anticipated debate: ‚ÄúIs Prop Trading Good for the Industry?‚Äù Brendan argued against the motion ‚Äî and the audience voted him the winner. In this interview, Brendan explains the reasoning behind his position. He walks through the message he believes many firms avoid: that the current prop trading model is too dependent on fees, too loose on risk, and too confusing for retail audiences. We discuss why he thinks the model grew fast, why it may run into walls, and what he believes is needed for a cleaner, more responsible version of prop trading. This is Brendan at his frankest ‚Äî sharp, grounded, and very clear about what changes are overdue.
